In this problem, you need to check if a given finite sequence appears as a sub-sequence in the Fibonacci sequence. The Fibonacci sequence is an infinite sequence defined as follows:
F(0) = 0
F(1) = 1
F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2) for n 2
Expanding using this rule, we get F(2) = 1, F(3) = 2, F(4) = 3, F(5) = 5, F(6) = 8, F(7) = 13, ..., etc. Note that F(n) increases as n increases.
A finite sequence is said to be a Fibonacci sub-sequence if it is contained in the Fibonacci sequence in the same relative order but not necessarily consecutively. For example, the finite sequence 2, 5, 8 is a Fibonacci sub-sequence. But 2, 8, 5 is not; nor is 1, 2, 4.
Task: Write a C++ program to accept an integer M followed by a finite sequence of M numbers. Your task is to determine if this finite sequence is a Fibonacci sub-sequence (i.e., all the numbers in the given finite sequence appear in the Fibonacci sequence in the same order).
Output:  You should output either true or false:
true: if the given finite sequence is a Fibonacci sub-sequence. E.g., on inputs "3 3 8 13" (first number 3 denotes the length of the finite sequence) and "3 5 8".
false: otherwise. E.g., on inputs "3 4 9 10", "3 2 3 9", and "3 2 8 5".
Example:
true: For input "3 3 8 13" (since 3, 8, and 13 appear in the Fibonacci sequence as "3 8 13")
false: For input "3 4 9 10", since 4, 9, and 10 do not appear as a sub-sequence in the Fibonacci sequence.
Input Format:  An integer M followed by M integers, all separated by space
Output Format
"true" if the sub-sequence exists in the Fibonacci sequence.
"false" if the sub-sequence does not exist in the Fibonacci sequence.
Assumptions on Input
Assume that the integer M will be between 1 and 19, both inclusive.
Assume that the sub-sequence numbers will be between 0 and 5000, both inclusive.
Note
Do not write any C++ statements for printing general messages. For example, the following should NOT be present in your program:
cout << "Enter a number:";
cout << "The computed answer is", etc.
cout should be used to print only the computed final output. In addition, do not print unnecessary spaces unless specified in the program.
If any hard coding is found, or if any test case passes by merely writing a cout statement and without any logic, then the marks for that test case will NOT be awarded.

No.   Input    Output      Explanation
p1   3 2 5 8   true   (2 5 8) is a Fibonacci sub-sequence

p2   3 1 1 4   false   (1 1 4) is not a Fibonacci sub-sequence. Its longest prefix that is a Fibonacci sub-sequence is (1 1).

p3   2 1 4   false   (1 4) is not a sub-sequence. Its longest prefix that is a Fibonacci sub-sequence is (1).

p3   4 0 1 1 2   true   (0 1 1 2) is a Fibonacci sub-sequence

p4   3 4 8 12   false   (4 8 12) is not a Fibonacci sub-sequence. 4 does not occur in the Fibonacci sequence

p5   3 4 8 13   false   (4 8 13) is not a Fibonacci sub-sequence. 4 does not occur in the Fibonacci sequence

p6   3 1 1 1   false   (1 1 1) is not a Fibonacci sub-sequence. (1 1) is the longest prefix that is a Fibonacci sub-sequence.

### Code : 
#include<simplecpp>
int nfib(int n){
    if (n==1){
        return 0;
    }
    else if(n==2){
        return 1;
    }
    else
    return nfib(n-1)+nfib(n-2);

}
main_program{
    int M;
    cin>>M;
    int i=1;
    repeat(M){
    int a;
    cin>>a;
    while(i<=30){
        if(a==nfib(i)){
            i++;
            break;
        }
        i++;
        

    }}
    if(i==31)
    cout<<"false";
    else
    cout<<"true";
}
